This Massive Hillside Figure Has Mystified Historians for Centuries. Now, Donations Have Secured the Surrounding Landscape
The National Trust has purchased the land around England‚Äôs Cerne Abbas Giant, which will help protect the mysterious chalk figure and nearby wildlife for future generations
On a green hillside in southern England, near the small village of Cerne Abbas in Dorset, a 180-foot-tall giant with a 35-foot-long erect phallus has lurked for hundreds of years.
Constructed by carving trenches into the hill and then packing them with chalk, the Cerne Abbas Giant wields a club in one hand and bears expressive features on his face. Despite the giant‚Äôs somewhat intimidating appearance, a recent fundraising campaign to buy the land surrounding the figure is proof that he is quite popular around the world. The acquisition of the 341 acres known as the Giant‚Äôs Lair will improve access to the landmark, secure archaeological research sites and provide opportunities for native species conservation.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm so pleased to start the new year with such a powerful example of people coming together and raising money to give nature the helping hand it needs,‚Äù National Trust director-general Hilary McGrady tells the Express‚Äô Matt Nixson.
The National Trust, a British conservation organization, has owned and managed the small plot of land on which the giant rests since 1920. In 2025, the land surrounding the giant went on sale to the chagrin of locals and conservationists. After raising more than $2.7 million with grants and bequests, the National Trust announced a fundraiser for the final $450,000. In just two months, the organization met its goal with gifts from 20 countries, including Australia, Japan, Ireland and Iceland.
Luke Dawson, the National Trust‚Äôs lead ranger for west Dorset and Cranborne Chase, tells the Guardian‚Äôs Steven Morris, ‚ÄúThe giant is a bit of a folk icon and brings in interest from all spheres. It has that mystical quality that piques a lot of people‚Äôs interest.‚Äù
Like many folk icons, the Cerne Abbas Giant‚Äôs story is still murky. The first known written reference to the figure is a 1694 account from a churchwarden, written in terms that suggested the region was long familiar with the giant. For many years, archaeologists speculated that the giant was prehistoric, but that theory was dashed by a 2020 analysis that found snail shells from species that didn‚Äôt arrive in England until the medieval era. A year later, testing of sand samples from the base of the pictograph‚Äôs trenches narrowed the giant‚Äôs creation to sometime between 700 and 1100 C.E.
Quick fact: The first record of the Cerne Abbas Giant
According to the 1694 account, three shillings were allocated for the purpose of ‚Äúrepairing of ye giant.‚Äù
Dating the pictograph to the early medieval period has also helped researchers to more accurately speculate on the identity of the giant. A 2024 study posed the now-popular theory that the ambiguous figure is actually meant to be the mythological hero Hercules. It may have been positioned on the hillside as a rallying point for troops battling the Vikings, though further research is needed to contextualize this possibility. Artlyst writes, ‚ÄúWith more of the surrounding land now accessible, researchers will be able to examine patterns of settlement and ritual activity across a much broader area.‚Äù
For the National Trust, this land acquisition was as much about preserving the giant‚Äôs surrounding landscape as it was about protecting the giant. As Hannah Jefferson, the National Trust‚Äôs general manager of the Dorset region, says in a statement, ‚ÄúWe can now set about creating a patchwork or mosaic of habitats to help species adapt and thrive.‚Äù
Building this ‚Äúmosaic of habitats‚Äù will include the restoration of the area‚Äôs grasslands, the planting of new woodlands and protection for hazel gloves fungus, which only grows in the area‚Äôs temperate rainforests. The National Trust also plans to partner with the organization Butterfly Conservation to create habitats for the 36 butterfly species that live in the Giant‚Äôs Lair, including the rare and fickle Duke of Burgundy butterfly.
By early February, the land surrounding the giant was officially in the National Trust‚Äôs care, as Jefferson tells BBC News‚Äô Marcus White. She adds that officials are starting to ‚Äúget to know it better‚Äù and planning for its future.
‚ÄúWe can now start creating a nature haven around the giant, the next chapter in his long history,‚Äù Sian Wilkinson, the head of public fundraising at the National Trust, tells the Guardian. ‚ÄúThis appeal shows we can do bold things when people come together.‚Äù

Scientists Say That Jupiter‚Äîthe Solar System‚Äôs Largest Planet‚ÄîMight Be Slightly Smaller Than Previously Thought
Updated measurements from NASA‚Äôs Juno spacecraft could help researchers better understand the planet‚Äôs mysterious interior, as well as other gas giants
Scientists may have been overestimating the size of the solar system‚Äôs biggest planet.
New data from NASA‚Äôs Juno spacecraft hint that Jupiter is a bit thinner and flatter than previously thought, although the updated numbers won‚Äôt take away its record-holding title among its planetary peers. The findings are described in a study published February 2 in Nature Astronomy.
Previously, Jupiter‚Äôs shape estimate was based on just six measurements made by NASA‚Äôs Voyager and Pioneer missions almost 50 years ago. The spacecraft transmitted radio signals through the planet‚Äôs atmosphere toward Earth, and how those waves slowed or bent‚Äîdue to atmospheric temperature, pressure and other characteristics‚Äîprovided information used to calculate the gas giant‚Äôs size. The technique is called radio occultation.
But the decades-old measurements ‚Äúdo not account for the influence of Jupiter‚Äôs strong winds,‚Äù the study authors write in the paper.
Did you know? The solar system‚Äôs smallest planet
On the opposite end of the size spectrum lies Mercury, which is about 3,000 miles wide at its equator. That‚Äôs roughly one-third the width of Earth.
To get an updated picture of the planet, researchers used the same method with signals sent from the Juno spacecraft, which has been circling Jupiter since 2016. They relied on 24 measurements that were taken during a new orbital route‚Äîin which the probe moves behind the gas giant from Earth‚Äôs point of view‚Äîthat began a few years ago, per a statement.
‚ÄúJuno‚Äôs passing behind Jupiter provides an opportunity for new science objectives,‚Äù says study co-author Scott J. Bolton, Juno‚Äôs principal investigator and a planetary scientist at the Southwest Research Institute, in the statement. ‚ÄúWhen the spacecraft passes behind the planet, its radio communication signal is blocked and bent by Jupiter‚Äôs atmosphere. This enables an accurate measurement of Jupiter‚Äôs size.‚Äù
Analyses revealed that the planet is about 83,000 miles tall along its polar axis and 89,000 miles wide along its equator. That‚Äôs roughly 15 miles and 5 miles smaller, respectively, than previously estimated.
The findings have implications for more than the planet‚Äôs silhouette.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not about just knowing exactly where the radius is, but it‚Äôs really about understanding its internal workings,‚Äù Oded Aharonson, a planetary scientist at the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel, who didn‚Äôt participate in the study, told New Scientist‚Äôs Alex Wilkins when the researchers presented their findings at the Europlanet Science Congress in September. ‚ÄúThe planet‚Äôs interior is mysterious and otherwise hard to probe, so having these new constraints could help us build more accurate interior models.‚Äù
The updated numbers are already resolving some previous problems, says study co-author Eli Galanti, a planetary scientist at the Weizmann Institute of Science, in the statement. ‚ÄúShifting the radius by just a little lets our models of Jupiter‚Äôs interior fit both the gravity data and atmospheric measurements much better.‚Äù
Given that scientists use Jupiter to study gas giants beyond the solar system, the new findings may also help researchers better understand this entire class of planets.
The team‚Äôs revised estimate of Jupiter‚Äôs size means that ‚Äútextbooks will need to be updated,‚Äù study co-author Yohai Kaspi, a geophysicist at the Weizmann Institute of Science, says in the statement. ‚ÄúThe size of Jupiter hasn‚Äôt changed, of course, but the way we measure it has.‚Äù

Archaeologists Are Finally Unraveling the Secrets of the Shipwreck Discovered 20 Feet Below the Streets of Manhattan
Researchers are opening a new investigation into the timbers, which may have once belonged to the ‚ÄúTyger,‚Äù a Dutch trading vessel that sank in 1613
In 1613, a Dutch ship known as the Tyger crossed the Atlantic and anchored in what is now New York Harbor. Captained by explorer Adriaen Block, the vessel was an early arrival to what would soon become the Dutch colonial settlement of New Amsterdam‚Äîlater renamed New York City. Months after the Tyger‚Äôs arrival, it was destroyed in a fire.
Three centuries later, in 1916, construction workers building a subway in Manhattan found the charred remains of a wooden ship‚Äôs keelson‚Äîwhich secures the keel‚Äôs framework‚Äîand three rib frames about 20 feet underground. James A. Kelly, the foreman of the subway construction crew, fought to save the artifacts, ‚Äúworking against a tight construction schedule and timbers that were tough to budge,‚Äù according to Artnet‚Äôs Min Chen. Experts concluded that the wreckage was likely the Tyger.
Since the 1940s, the timbers have belonged to the Museum of the City of New York (MCNY). In recent decades, ‚Äúthere has been renewed interest in [their] attribution,‚Äù per a statement from the museum. Now, researchers are launching a new investigation to learn more about the wood‚Äôs type, age and geographic origin.
The research will be conducted by archaeologist Martijn Manders, program leader of the International Program for Maritime Heritage at the Netherlands‚Äô Cultural Heritage Agency, and dendrochronologist Marta Dom√≠nguez-Delm√°s, a senior researcher at the Dutch Naturalis Biodiversity Center and the Cultural Heritage Agency.
‚ÄúTree rings in the shipwreck timbers can reveal the date and provenance of the wood, and while they cannot tell us explicitly whether this is the Tyger, they can certainly reveal if it is not,‚Äù Dom√≠nguez-Delm√°s says in the statement.
She adds that if the timbers date to after the vessel‚Äôs construction, or if they‚Äôre a type of wood not used in early 17th-century Dutch shipbuilding, researchers will be able to rule out the Tyger. But if the dates and tree species line up, ‚Äúwe will be able to reach an informed conclusion.‚Äù
Block sailed the Tyger from Amsterdam for a trading mission: A company had hired him to acquire beaver and otter furs through trade with the Lenape. But after a fire destroyed the ship, Block spent the winter ashore, and the Lenape helped him build a new vessel, the Onrust. In 1614, Block used the Onrust to explore and map the East River, Connecticut River and Long Island Sound.
Quick fact: The island named for Adriaen Block
Block Island, located off the coast of Rhode Island, is named for the Dutch trader, who landed there in 1614.
‚ÄúHis cartographic work corrected key geographic misconceptions and laid the groundwork for future Dutch colonization in the region,‚Äù Margaret Connors McQuade, MCNY‚Äôs director of collections, told National Geographic‚Äôs Ronan O‚ÄôConnell in July 2025.
The Dutch‚Äîand later British‚Äîsettlers of Manhattan soon found they wanted more land to build on. They expanded the island by piling dirt and garbage past the shoreline, creating more land, according to National Geographic. This expanded shore eventually buried the location of the sunken Tyger, which explains why construction workers found it underground centuries later.
The new research will focus on eight feet of ship keel and ribs, McQuade told National Geographic. But ship structures weren‚Äôt the only artifacts the construction crew unearthed at the shipwreck site. ‚ÄúAlong with the timbers, they uncovered a Dutch broad-headed ax, trade beads, clay pipes, a length of chain, a small cannon and shards of blue and white pottery,‚Äù McQuade said.
Dom√≠nguez-Delm√°s says in the statement that the artifacts and the dendrochronological research on the timbers will help contextualize the ship‚Äôs discovery. The researchers will also ‚Äústudy the timbers as shipbuilding elements, examining how they were made, their function within the vessel, and what they reveal about construction techniques,‚Äù per the statement.
Block arrived in what‚Äôs now New York on the Tyger just a few years after Henry Hudson, the English navigator hired by the Dutch East India Company. In the years that followed, the Dutch founded the colony of New Netherland and its capital, New Amsterdam. In 1664, the British conquered New Amsterdam and renamed it New York.
‚ÄúThe quest to confirm the Tyger‚Äôs identity is not just a scientific endeavor; it is a journey into the city‚Äôs earliest days,‚Äù MCNY president Stephanie Hill Wilchfort told National Geographic.

Air Pollution Can Cause Some Ants to Turn on One Another‚Äîand Neglect Their Young, New Research Suggests
The findings further hint that air pollution, particularly ozone, is contributing to the ‚Äúinsect apocalypse‚Äù
Air pollution is known to cause health problems in humans, such as respiratory issues and cancer, so it might not be surprising that it also affects other creatures. But in ants, the common pollutant ozone can quickly turn friends into enemies: Exposure to the gas can change how an ant smells, causing its nestmates to viciously attack it, according to a new study.
The findings, published February 2 in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, further hint that air pollution might contribute to the global decline of bugs known as the ‚Äúinsect apocalypse.‚Äù
Most of Earth‚Äôs ozone, a compound made of three oxygen atoms, sits high in the atmosphere and helps shield life from the sun‚Äôs radiation. But pollutants from cars, power plants and other sources can chemically react when exposed to sunlight and create harmful ozone at ground level.
Ants send messages to colony members through odor compounds that contain alkenes, chemicals that help nestmates recognize one another, which can be degraded by ozone. And past research suggests that ozone alters chemical communication in some insects, like fruit flies.
‚ÄúWe wanted to know if exposure to increased ozone levels would alter the ants‚Äô odor signature, resulting in aggression upon their return to the colony,‚Äù says study co-author Nan-Ji Jiang, a biologist at the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology in Germany, in a statement. ‚ÄúThe crucial question for us was: Could air pollution disrupt the delicate social structure of ant colonies?‚Äù
Quick fact: Insect apocalypse
Long-term monitoring of 452 invertebrate species‚Äîmost of which are insects‚Äîhints that their overall global population has shrunk by about 45 percent from 1970 to 2010. The number of butterflies and moths, a group called Lepidoptera, has declined by about 35 percent within that timeframe‚Äîand that drop is less severe than those seen in other types of invertebrates.
To conduct the study, Jiang and his colleagues set up an experiment with six different ant species. They placed one ant from each colony into a chamber with either ambient air or an ozone concentration of 100 parts per billion, a level often measured in highly polluted regions, like some dense cities. After 20 minutes, the researchers reintroduced the ants to their colonies, and nestmates of most species showed aggression toward the ozone-exposed insects.
‚ÄúI did not expect it, I have to say,‚Äù study co-author Markus Knaden, a neuroethologist at the Max Planck Institute of Chemical Ecology, tells Chiara Marchisio at New Scientist. ‚ÄúBecause knowing that alkenes are such a minor part [of the ants‚Äô scent], we knew that whatever we did with ozone would only change maybe 2 percent or 5 percent of the blend.‚Äù
Only one species, clonal raider ants, didn‚Äôt ambush a colony member with an off scent. The researchers suspect that this might stem from the species‚Äô unique biology, per the statement. Unlike many ant species, clonal raider ants lack queens and show little aggression toward members of other colonies.
To investigate long-term impacts of ozone exposure, the researchers exposed small colonies of clonal raider ants with larvae to either ambient air or 100 ppb of ozone for 12 days. During that time, adults of ozone-polluted nests stayed farther away from their larvae than those in the control colonies. Many larvae in the ozone group died, probably because of abandonment rather than air pollution poisoning, according to further analyses. The team suspects that the toxic gas disrupted the chemical signals that normally tell adult ants to care for their young.
Daniel Kronauer, an insect biologist at Rockefeller University who was not involved in the new work, tells New Scientist that the ants‚Äô aggressive reactions to ozone-exposed colony members weren‚Äôt surprising to him, because alkenes are crucial to nestmate recognition.
As insect populations decline around the world, the findings further point to air pollutants as a possible cause, in addition to pesticides, light pollution and other factors. The work is especially important given the crucial role ants play in maintaining healthy habitats, such as dispersing seeds, controlling pests and aerating soil.
‚ÄúOxidizing pollutants such as ozone and nitrogen oxides are often discussed because of their harmful effects on humans,‚Äù says study co-author Bill Hansson, a biologist at the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology. ‚ÄúHowever, we should also be aware that these man-made pollutants can also cause significant damage to our ecosystems.‚Äù
